title: Why you might want to open a Help to Buy ISA before the deadline
text:
From Cosmopolitan

The Help to Buy ISA deadline is a little over two months away on 30 November 2019, which means there's limited time if you want to invest money towards buying your first house. But is it worth committing now? And if you do decide to invest, which bank offers the best Help to Buy ISA interest rate?

How does a Help to Buy ISA work?

Lucy Mullins, Co-Founder and Head of Membership at StepLadder – the start-up helping young people climb onto the housing ladder, explained the scheme to Cosmopolitan UK.

"The government will boost the money you have saved by 25% with a maximum bonus of £3,000 a year," she said." Basically, if you save £100, the government will give you a bonus of £25, making your total £125.

"What’s more, like other ISAs, the money you receive is tax free so you could earn up to 2.6% interest, depending on who you open your account with. Help to Buy ISAs are available from a range of different banks and building societies so it is well worth shopping around (although tax treatment is subject to individual circumstances and change.)"

Photo credit: baona - Getty Images More

We've laid out all the info, so you can compare which bank offers the best Help to Buy ISA for you...

Note: AER stands for Annual Equivalent Rate, or the interest rate you earn on your savings

Halifax Help to Buy ISA

The rate for the Halifax ISA is a reasonable 2.25% AER / 2.25% tax-free. You can make unlimited withdrawals, too, but as with any Help to Buy ISA, you won’t be able to claim the Government bonus on the funds you withdraw.

FIND OUT MORE

Barclays Help to Buy ISA

Barclays has a high interest rate of 2.58% AER / 2.55% tax-free per year, but only those with an existing account will be able to open online - the others will need to visit a branch. The interest rate is variable, so it's probably best for someone who's willing to keep an eye on it... if you're the 'open and leave'-type, this might not be the ISA for you.

FIND OUT MORE

Nationwide Help to Buy ISA

The Nationwide ISA offers a 2.5% AER/tax-free interest rate but, unlike Barclays, allows you to "split", meaning you can pay into both a Help to Buy and Cash ISA in the same year. Ideal if you're intent on saving as much as you can, as quickly as you can.

FIND OUT MORE

Natwest Help to Buy ISA

Much like the above, the NatWest ISA has a 2.50% AER / 2.47% tax-free rate and will also let you split. There's no withdrawal fee, and it's easy to open in the branch, online or over the phone.

FIND OUT MORE

Lloyds Help to Buy ISA

The Lloyds IA has a 1.50% tax free/AER variable interest, but is easy to open. Plus, the bank will let you know if interest rates change, which is nice.

FIND OUT MORE

HSBC Help to Buy ISA

HSBC allows you to open a Help to Buy ISA online, in a branch, by telephone or by post, and the rate is 2.25% AER / 2.23% tax free.

FIND OUT MORE

Santander Help to Buy ISA

Santander has a rate of 1.75% AER/tax-free, but that is upped to 2.25% AER/tax-free if you’re part of 1|2|3 World or Santander Select.

FIND OUT MORE

Is a Help to Buy ISA worth it for me?

As with any lending scheme, there are chances the Help to Buy ISA might not be quite right for you.

Firstly, it's worth bearing in mind when you want to buy. "You have until 30th November 2029 to continue saving, and you’ll still get the bonus as long as you use it by the 1st of December 2030," explains Lucy. But, as you can only save a maximum of £200 per month after the initial £1,200 deposit, it takes nearly five years to save the £12,000 you need to gain the maximum government bonus - so maybe it's not perfect if you've got your sights set on being an owner ASAP.
